review.title: On the Effects of Low-Quality Training Data on Information Extraction from Clinical Reports
review.abstract: In the last five years there has been a flurry of work on information extraction from clinical documents, i.e., on algorithms capable of extracting, from the informal and unstructured texts that are generated during everyday clinical practice, mentions of concepts relevant to such practice. Most of this literature is about methods based on supervised learning, i.e., methods for training an information extraction system from manually annotated examples. While a lot of work has been devoted to devising learning methods that generate more and more accurate information extractors, no work has been devoted to investigating the effect of the quality of training data on the learning process. Low quality in training data often derives from the fact that the person who has annotated the data is different from the one against whose judgment the automatically annotated data must be evaluated. In this paper we test the impact of such data quality issues on the accuracy of information extraction systems as applied to the clinical domain. We do this by comparing the accuracy deriving from training data annotated by the authoritative coder (i.e., the one who has also annotated the test data, and by whose judgment we must abide), with the accuracy deriving from training data annotated by a different coder. The results indicate that, although the disagreement between the two coders (as measured on the training set) is substantial, the difference is (surprisingly enough) not always statistically significant.

sections.heading: On the Effects of Low-Quality Training Data on Information Extraction from Clinical Reports
sections.text: DIEGO MARCHEGGIANI, Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche FABRIZIO SEBASTIANI, Qatar Computing Research InstitutesIn the last five years there has been a flood of work on the extraction of information from clinical documents, that is, on algorithms that are able to extract from the informal and unstructured texts that are generated during the day of clinical practice, mentions of concepts relevant to such a practice. Most of this literature is aboutmethods based on supervised learning, i.e., methods for the formation of an information system from manual annotated examples. While a lot of work has been devoted to the development of learning methods that generate more and more precise information extractors, no work has been devoted to studying the effects of the quality of training data on the learning process.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Over the past five years, there has been a flood of work results (see e.g. [Kelly et al. 2014; Pradhan et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2013; Suominen et al. 2013; Uzuner et al. 2012; Uzuner et al. 2011]) on extracting information from clinical documents, i.e. algorithms capable of extracting from informal and unstructured texts generated during day-to-day clinical practice (e.g. approval reports, radiological reports, relief reports, clinical notes), mentions of concepts relevant to such practice. Most of this literature is about methods based on verified learning, i.e., methods for training and information gathering from manually annotated examples. While a lot of work has been devoted to developing text representations and variants of aforensised learning methods that produce more and more accurate information, no work is devoted to investigating the quality effects of learning processes on learning processes.

sections.heading: 1.1. Our contribution
sections.text: In this paper, we are testing the impact of training data on the accuracy of information systems as applied in practice. We are doing this by testing the accuracy of two state-of-the-art systems on a dataset of radiology reports (originally published in [Esuli et al. 2013]) in which a portion of the data is commented on by two different experts. In other words, we are trying to answer the question: "What is the consequence of the fact that my training data is not stereotypical? that the coders that produced it are not fully elastic? How much will I lose in terms of the accuracy of the trained system?"

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1. Information extraction from clinical documents
sections.text: Most work on information extraction from clinical documents is based on methods based on supervised learning, i.e. methods for training an information extraction system from manually annotated examples. Supporting vector machines (SVMs - [Jiang et al. 2011; Li et al. 2008; Sibanda et al. 2006]), hidden Markov models (HMMs - [Li et al. 2010]), and (in particular) random conditional fields (CRFs - [Esuli et al. 2013; Gupta et al. 2014; Jiang et al. 2011; Jonnalagadda et al. 2012; Li et al. 2008; Patrick and Li 2010; Torii et al. 2011; Wang and Patrick 2009]) were the preferred learners in this field due to their good performance and the existence of publicly available implementations. In recent years, research on the analysis of clinical texts has been further boosted by the existence of "common tasks" on this topic, such as the Uzundifor Epynology Study Bezal (Bezal).

sections.heading: 2.2. Low-quality training data and prediction accuracy
sections.text: The literature on the impact of sub-optimal training data on predictive accuracy is extremely scarce, even within machine learning literature. An early study is [Rossin and Klein] looking at these questions in the context of a linear regression model that leads them to the bizarre conclusion that "predictive accuracy in training data is better than in training data," while the opposite conclusion is drawn from experiments with a linear regression model.

sections.heading: 3.3. Learning algorithms
sections.text: Since the learning algorithms we have used in this paper have not been able to locate another time-mixed database protocol containing clinical texts that are not publicly available (LC-CRFs - [Lafferty et al. 2001; Sutton and McCallum 2007; Sutton and McCallum 2012]), in Charles Sutton's GRMM implementation7, and hidden Markov support vector machines (HM-SVMs - [Altun et al. 2003]), in Thorsten Joachim's SVMhmm implementation8. Both are supervised learning algorithms explicitly designed for sequence labeling, i.e. for learning to label elements that occur naturally in sequences and such that the labeling of an element depends on the characteristics and / or on the labels of other elements that precede or follow that sequence (which is actually the case for the text in a token).

sections.heading: 3.4. Evaluation measures
sections.text: 3.4.1. Classification Accuracy. As a measure of classification accuracy, similar to [Esuli et al = 2013], we use the token and delimiter variant (proposed in [Esuli and Sebastiani 2010]) of the well-known formula 1, according to which an information extraction system is evaluated on an event space consisting of all t units in the text. In other words, each t unit xt (rather than every mention, as in the traditional "segmentation phenomenon F-Score" model, counts as true positive, true negative, false positive or false negative for a given concept cr, depending on whether xt belongs to cr or not. This model has the advantage of recognizing a system for partial success (i.e., degree of overlap between a predicted mention and a true mention for the same concept), and penalizing both over-annotation.

sections.heading: 4. RESULTS

sections.heading: 4.1. Experimental protocol
sections.text: In [Esuli et al. 2013] the experiments on the UmbertoI (RadRep) dataset play two roles of Coder1. Each dataset was executed with either 1-only and / or 2-only (i.e. the parts of the data that only one encoder commented on) as training data and both (1) and / or both (2) (i.e. the part of the data that both encoders had recorded, in both versions) as test data. In this essay we alternate the roles of the training and test sets, i.e. we use both (1) and (2) as training set (since we need training data with multiple, alternative annotations for the purpose of this work) and only 1-only as a test set. Specifically, we perform two batch experiments, Batch1 and Batch2. In Batch1 Coder1 Coder1 plays the role of the authoritative encoder (Cα) and Coder2 the role of the non-authoritative encoder (Cβ).

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Few researchers have investigated the loss of accuracy that occurs when a supervised learning algorithm is fed with training data of sub-optimal quality. We have done this for the first time in the case of information extraction systems (trained through supervised learning), as applied to the collection of mentions of concepts of interest in medical notes. Specifically, we have tested the extent to which the extraction accuracy suffers when the person who commented on the test data (the "authoritative coder") whom we must assume is the person whose judgment we judge independently of their expertise, unlike the person who labeled the training data (the "non-authoritative coders"). Our experimental results, obtained on a dataset of 500 mammographic reports recorded according to 9 concepts of interest, are somewhat surprising, since they indicate that the resulting drop in accuracy is not always statistically significant.

In the context of a biomedical information extraction task Haddow and Alex [2008] examined the situation in which training data annotated by two different coders are available, and they found that higher accuracy is obtained by using both versions at the same time than by attempting to reconcile them or using just one of them.
Closer to our application context, Esuli and Sebastiani [2013] have thoroughly studied the effect of suboptimal training data quality in text classification.

Webber and Pickens [2013] also address the text classification task (in the context of ediscovery from legal texts), but differently from [Esuli and Sebastiani 2013] they work with naturally occurring noise; differently from the present work, the multiply-coded training data they use were coded by one coder known to be an expert coder and another coder known to be a junior coder.

HM-SVMs are an instantiation of “SVMs for structured output prediction” (SVM ) [Tsochantaridis et al. 2005] for the sequence labelling task, and have already been used in clinical information extraction (see e.
, [Tang et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2014]).
, [Tang et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2014]).

As a measure of classification accuracy we use, similarly to [Esuli et al. 2013], the token-and-separator variant (proposed in [Esuli and Sebastiani 2010]) of the well-known F1 measure, according to which an information extraction system is evaluated on an event space consisting of all the t-units in the text.

In other words, each t-unit xt (rather than each mention, as in the traditional “segmentation F-score” model [Suzuki et al. 2006]) counts as a true positive, true negative, false positive, or false negative for a given concept cr, depending on whether xt belongs to cr or not in the predicted annotation and in the true annotation.
